body: No, because having a.AVI and a.avi on Linux is perfectly valid, and they are two separate files.

So what? Everybody knows this, but still there would be probably many users who would happily configure syncthing to ignore case in ignore patterns, so that *.avi matches all avi files, no matter of case used in suffix.

Or you should at least implement regular expressions so that users can define this themselves
Can you give me a valid use case where user would want to ignore all *.mp3 files but not *.MP3 files? Except for some weird freaks, I can't think of any.

Just one random fact to educate you little bit: having two files with same name but different letter case, like a, A has nothing to do with linux (you said "on linux") it's a long term POSIX standard that is supported by many UNIX filesystems far longer than linux does exist...

Don't forget that ignore files are not only for extensions, hence I can clearly see cases where I would like to ignore `*somestring*` but not `*SOMESTRING*`.

Yeah, Linux very rarely uses FAT32 which is the only alive FS I am aware of which is not case sensitive.
Given majority of the FS'es are case sensitive, I don't see why we shouldn't respect that?

It does use regular expressions under the hood, but I doubt anyone from a non-technical background knows how to write one, hence it's not a very user friendly option.

rename.to: option to create case insensitive entry in ignore patterns

body: While I really don't like being called weird freak, having something like `i:*.avi` translated to `/.*\.avi/i` doesn't sounds impossible...

I didn't know syncthing is designed only for people with no technical background

Anyway, there should be at least option to create case insensitive entry in the list, something like i/pattern goes here/ etc

On other hand, doesn't this...

https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/d9fd27a9e804aed1a17c17912d9894a26c277439/internal/fnmatch/fnmatch.go#L27

... means that patterns are case-insensitive on Windows anyway?
On windows maybe, but I am using linux
FWIW, HSF+ (uses by the macheads out there) is also case-insensitive by default.
Patterns are case insensitive on Mac and Windows, case sensitive everywhere else. It would be useful to be able to create case insensitive patterns there as well, I guess.
What about allowing `(?i)` as a control parameter?

issue.title: .stignore: support `!(?)` combination, and `somepattern/` to match only directories

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
It seems to me that the current .stignore format makes it impossible to implement a simple use case: to only synchronize files with a certain file extension. I think there are two problems with the current format.

First, I tried to mark the files with the desired extension as included:

```
!(?)*.jpg
!(?)*.png
```

This already did not work, as it is not possible to use both `!` and `(?)` as a prefix. I tried both `!(?)` and `(?)!`, none seemed to be working.

Second, I did not find a satisfying way to exclude the rest of the directory structure. Of course, simply

```
*
```

does not work, as it matches all directories, stopping syncthing from looking inside them. The next best thing is probably

```
*.*
```

but this also excludes directories (and their contents) with a `.` inside. Plus, it does not exclude files without a `.`. What is necessary is a distinction between patterns that match directories and patterns that match files. I think the approach taken by git (http://git-scm.com/docs/gitignore) is sensible: everything that ends with a `/` matches directories only and everything else matches files only.

What do you think?
